title: 110_hr3599
content: The "Creating Access to Rides Act" allows for grants to low-income car ownership programs. The Social Security Act is amended to include grants for low-income car ownership programs, aiming to help low-income families access affordable automobiles for better employment opportunities and training. States, tribes, localities, and nonprofits are encouraged to develop and manage programs providing assistance with car ownership for low-income families. In this paragraph, definitions are provided for key terms such as "locality," "low-income families," and "nonprofit entity." The Secretary may award grants to promote improving access to affordable automobiles by low-income families through nonprofit entities. Grant approval criteria will be established for applications. The grant criteria include consideration of improving access to training, employment, and child care services for low-income families through car ownership, level of innovation in the proposal, and partnerships between public and private sectors. Grants awarded must be used to administer programs assisting low-income families. The grant criteria for programs assisting low-income families with car ownership include supplementing, not supplanting, other public funds and exempting from certain rules under section 404. The applicant must submit an application to the Secretary for a grant under this paragraph, following specific requirements. The Secretary may redistribute unspent grant funds among other grantees if not used within 3 years. Administrative costs are limited to 5% of funds appropriated for grants. Evaluation will be conducted through grants. The Secretary will conduct evaluations of programs funded by grants and there is an authorization of $50,000,000 for grants each year from 2008 to 2012. Additionally, funds from Individual Development Accounts under the TANF program can now be used for car ownership, maintenance, and insurance. Qualified automotive expenditures can now be paid from individual development accounts directly to the persons due. The definition of qualified automotive expenditures includes expenses for purchasing or maintaining a car, as well as insurance. Accounts established under the Assets for Independence Act can now include these expenditures. The Assets for Independence Act now allows qualified automotive expenditures to be paid directly from individual development accounts to the recipients. This includes expenses for buying or maintaining a car, as well as insurance.
